occurrences.line_text: And how ye may him hence, and to what part
My selfe will beare a part, coportion of your packe.
And euery part, that vnder sweathbands lay,
But gan himselfe addresse to take her part.
To reskue him, and his weake part abet,
And eke all knights hast shamed with this knightlesse part.
Whooping, and hallowing on euery part,
And of the pray each one a part doth beare.
That her alone he for his part desired
Or die with you in sorrow, and partake your griefe.
My friend, hight Philemon, I did partake
Her honest merth and pleasaunce to partake;
Way for themselues, their purpose to partake?
He then did put, her pleasures lenger to partake.
Not one (quoth he) but many doe partake
As if they secret counsels did partake;
But either sdeignes with other to partake:
Ne any dar'd their perill to partake;
Her selfe came in, her glory to partake;
And streight went forth his gladnesse to partake
With which none had to doe, ne ought partake,
To be partaker of her wandring woe,
Me reft from it, had bene partaker of the place.
How that thou art partaker of his crime:
My labour adde, and be partaker of their speed.
And be partakers of their euill plight,
Both ioynt partakers of the fatall paine:
And be partakers of thy endlesse fame.
Soone as she parted thence, the fearefull twaine,
So been they parted both, with harts on edge,
But ere they parted, Vna faire besought
Thus beene they parted, Arthur on his way
So parted we and on our iourney driue,
Was next adioyning, ne them parted ought:
Mongst whom he parted his imperiall state,
But when she parted hence, she left her groome
She parted thence, her anguish to appease.
So both tooke goodly leaue, and parted seuerall.
So taking courteous leaue, they parted twayne,
And twixt them both with parted paines did beare,
And fram'd of liquid ayre her tender partes
Her neather partes misshapen, monstruous,
Her flitting partes, and element vnsound,
A man, of many partes from beasts deriued,
His partes to reasons rule obedient,
And thrise three hundred thanks for my good partes
And richlier by many partes arayd:
What time his people into partes did riue,
She entred into all the partes entire.
And Sture, that parteth with his pleasant floods
The Parthian strikes a stag with shiuering dart,
Till partiall Paris dempt it Venus dew,
That in their proper prayse too partiall bee,
That liues, pertaines in charge particulare,
Who priuie was, and partie in the case:
And from her partie eftsoones was drawen cleene.
To hasten greatly to his parties ayd,
And at her parting said, She Queene of Faeries hight.
With cup thus charmd, him parting she deceiu'd;
So from her parting, she thenceforth did labour
Ten thousand kindes of creatures, partly male
And partly female of his fruitfull seed;
The frame thereof seemd partly circulare,
And Paridell though partly discontent
Partly with shame, and partly with dismay,
Partly with shame, and partly with dismay,
Which of my loue was partner Paramoure:
Hath found another partner of your payne:
Ne yet her Belamour, the partner of his sheet.
Like as a fearefull Partridge, that is fled
The guilefull great Enchaunter parts
He saw diuided into double parts,
And all the hinder parts, that few could spie,
And secret poyson through their inner parts,
She lightly sprinkled on his weaker parts;
That her misshaped parts did them appall,
Her neather parts, the shame of all her kind,
Dry-shod to passe, she parts the flouds in tway;
Drew them in parts, and each made others foe;
Is this the ioy of armes? be these the parts
Of her lewd parts to make companion;
That in thy selfe thy lesser parts do moue,
Her vpper parts of meet habiliments,
This parts great workmanship, & wondrous powre,
Might be compar'd to these by many parts:
From whence he brought them to these saluage parts,
That did her selfe in sundry parts diuide,
But that they ouerran all parts with easie hand.
Vpon the parts, brought into their bondage:
And scorned parts were mingled with the fine,)
Their dainty parts from vew of any, which them eyde.
In picturing the parts of beautie daint,
Brought her into those parts, and what inquest
For such intent into these parts I came,
His inward parts, and all his entrayles wast,
Aside, with faire Adonis playes his wanton parts.
And eke their lately bruzed parts to bring in plight.
And many wide woundes launched through his inner parts.
Her lying tongue was in two parts diuided,
And both the parts did speake, and both contended;
Which did her powre into three parts diuyde;
As one whose inner parts had bene ythrild
Till on her horses hinder parts it fell;
And there out sucking venime to her parts entyre.
From inward parts, with cancred malice lind,
From his false eyes, into their harts and parts entire.
From all foure parts of heauen doe rage full sore,
There gan they change their sides, and new parts take;
Then all his former parts did earst appere.
So all the rest did others parts empaire.
Where whilest her earthly parts with soft delight
And forth into the lower parts did pas;
Their dainty parts, which nature had created
Where none may be with her lewd parts defyled,
And euen to the vitall parts they past,
The foule discourt'sies and vnknightly parts,
The inner parts now gan to putrify,
In th'inner parts, and lastly scattering
Yet did her face and former parts professe
But all her hinder parts did plaine expresse
Those daintie parts, the dearlings of delight,
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
Through all the inner parts, wherein they dwelt,
And suddein parture of faire Florimell,
And with vnwearied powre his party still assured.
That weakens her, and makes her party strong:
And for this Mayd, whose party thou doest take,
Of straunge aduentures, which abroad did pas.
Far from resort of people, that did pas
With faire discourse the euening so they pas:
And high hath set his throne, where Tiberis doth pas.
By which she thought her wandring knight shold pas,
And on their former iourney forward pas,
Yet did she thinke her pearelesse wroth to pas
That night they pas in ioy and iollity,
They pas the bitter waues of Acheron,
And after him old Ninus farre did pas
Who with his breath, which through the world doth pas,
Perce to my hart, and pas through euery side,
A liue or dead: and forward forth doth pas,
The light whereof, that heauens light did pas,
But soone as breath out of his breast did pas,
Then asked he, which way he in might pas:
A drearie corse, whose life away did pas,
Was guests to welcome, towardes him did pas:
Thence forward by that painfull way they pas,
So dreadfully he towards him did pas,
My tongue can tell, so farre all sense they pas:
Sterne melancholy did his courage pas,
So forth they pas, a well consorted paire,
And vaine delight she saw he light did pas,
The one before, by which all in did pas,
That when it locked, none might thorough pas,
Which he recorded still, as they did pas,
But let them pas, whiles wind and weather right
Ne ought saue perill, still as he did pas:
Therein discouered was, ne ought mote pas,
Guided thy glaunce, to bring his will to pas:
The spoyle of all the world, that it did pas
By which both in and out men moten pas;
Thereto so swift, that it all beasts did pas:
Her to disport, and idle time to pas,
So soone as he the Prison dore did pas,
More for great sorrow, that he could not pas,
With heauenly notes, that did all other pas,
That though therein himselfe he thought to pas,
And fast beside a little brooke did pas
And yeeld vnto her weapon way to pas:
They tooke their steeds, and forward thence did pas
And vndiscerned, forth with him did pas.
Then lesse (said she) by all the woe I pas,
And twixt her selfe and Loue did let me pas;
Out of his Albion did on dry-foot pas
In swimming be expert through waters force to pas.
That Florimell her selfe she then did pas.
For Braggadochio would not let him pas;
Which that thou mayst the better bring to pas,
And forth into the lower parts did pas;
In crueltie and outrage she did pas,
That herein doest all earthly Princes pas?
Through many perils and much way did pas,
Fashion'd to please the eies of them, that pas,
On her faire feet by his horse side did pas
Ne wist which way he through the foord mote pas.
Now gan to faint, and further could not pas
They stayd not there, but streight way in did pas.
So as they forward on their way did pas,
That way to them he gaue forth right to pas.
Appeard for people in nor out to pas,
Yet playd Pasiphaï¿½ a more monstrous part,
Louely Pasithee, kinde Eulimene,
That hardly passable on foote it was:
Made rowme, and passage for them did prepaire:
And all that might his angrie passage stay,
To her yeeld passage, gainst his Lord to goe,
And made an open passage for the gushing flood.
And meetes a flood, that doth his passage stay,
What if some litle paine the passage haue,
That nothing might his ready passage stay:
And there by force vnwonted passage find,
But he for nought would stay his passage right,
But easie is the way, and passage plaine
But yielded passage to his cruell knife.
Appease his heat, or hastie passage stay;
They were farre past the passage, which he spake,
Where she was rowing, and for passage sought:
Till season serue new passage to assay;
But marched to the strond, their passage to require.
And yield him readie passage to that other part.
Awaiting passage, which him late did faile;
That wanton Mayd of passage had denide,
By further search had passage found elsewhere,
Through all those foldes the steelehead passage wrought
Into his head, and cruell passage made
Whereby her course is stopt, and passage staid.
Ne hedge ne ditch his readie passage brake,
An open passage through his riuen brest,
For here before a perlous passage lyes,
That therefore nought our passage may empeach,
Them yielded readie passage, and their rage surceast.
And through the brackish waues their passage sheare;
With cruell threats, his passage through the ford to let.
Him boldly bad his passage there to stay,
That his swift charet might haue passage wyde,
And passage bard to all, that thither came,
And in their flesh a griesly passage rend,
But by one way, that passage did prepare.
Next him went Wylibourne with passage slye,
That keepes a Bridges passage by strong hond,
That makes all men for feare that passage for to shonne.
Who as they to the passage gan to draw,
That passage money did of them require,
The lucky Pylot of her passage sad,
That in and out thou mayst haue passage free.
Streight was the passage like a ploughed ridge,
Nath'lesse that stroke so cruell passage found,
Ne once for ought her speedy passage stayd,
All times haue wont safe passage to afford
The armed knights stopping his passage by,
Into his shield it readie passage found,
It would no passage yeeld vnto his purpose vaine.
And that knights berd for toll, which they for passage pay.
So soone as passage is vnto him lent,
The couert was so thicke, that did no passage shew.
But he him makes his passage-penny pay:
That bore a Lion passant in a golden field.
And foorth they passe, with pleasure forward led,
May euer passe, but thorough great distresse.
By them the Sprite doth passe in quietly,
By them they passe, all gazing on them round,
But when he saw the Damsell passe away
Why wilt not let him passe, that long hath stood
Vpon the banke, yet wilt thy selfe not passe the flood?
Hight Humiltï¿½. They passe in stouping low;
Dry-shod to passe, she parts the flouds in tway;
To passe, for succour from the scorching ray,
Perdie (said Trompart) let her passe at will,
Wayting to passe, he saw whereas did swim
My litle boat can safely passe this perilous bourne.
And passe the bonds of modest merimake,
And striue to passe (as she could well enough)
They forward passe, ne Guyon yet spoke word,
Nor wight, nor word mote passe out of the gate,
We needes must passe (God do vs well acquight,)
Forward they passe, and strongly he them rowes,
And passe on forward: so their way does ly,
But suffered him to passe, all were she loth;
To passe; but maugre thee will passe or dy.
To passe; but maugre thee will passe or dy.
To bring to passe his mischieuous intent,
Mote algates passe; for thy, themselues they set
To passe that way, as forth he trauelled;
That all the antique Worthies merits far did passe.
But let him passe as lightly, as he came:
And gaue her leaue at pleasure forth to passe.
Quite ouerblowne, yet doth not passe so cleare,
Eftsoones his life may passe into the next;
To let them passe at will, for dread of shame.
Yet did the workmanship farre passe the cost:
She seem'd to passe: so forged things do fairest shew.
He all that night, that too long night did passe.
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
For louers heauen must passe by sorrowes hell.
So loue of soule doth loue of bodie passe,
For neuer wight he lets to passe that way,
With whom as he did passe by the sea shore,
To passe them ouer, where them list to tell:
For may no Knight nor Lady passe along
That way, (and yet they needs must passe that way),
To all, that passe. That shall you glory gaine
To visite, after this nights perillous passe,
They mote the abler be to passe vnto the rest.
Ne could it vpward come, nor downward passe,
To passe the tedious trauell of the way;
Into his Lords forbidden hall to passe.
Led by a Carle and foole, which by her side did passe.
A Baylieffe errant forth in post did passe,
To passe all others, on the earth which were:
Yet she all other countrey lasses farre did passe.
That nothing meet in marchandise to passe.
He passed forth, and new aduenture sought;
And oft her kist. At length all passed feare,
Of all her passed paines: one louing howre
Arriued there they passed in forth right;
But th'onely good, that growes of passed feare,
But glauncing by forth passed forward right;
And passed fairely forth. He turning taile,
Forth passed on their way in faire accord,
By them as Alma passed with her guestes,
Then gan this Realme renewe her passed prime:
Did couet, as they passed by that way,
So now to Guyon, as he passed by,
But passed forth, and lookt still forward right,
Themselues they forth conuayd, & passed forward right.
Her to encounter, ere she passed by:
Whom for remembraunce of her passed ioy,
But went his way; whom when he passed kend,
That through she passed; as a thunder bolt
Which done, she passed forth not taking leaue,
And as she passed through th'vnruly preace
So as they passed forth, they did espy
That did her passed paines in quiet rest assoyle.
So when that forrest they had passed well,
At last when they were passed out of sight,
The stone, which passed straunger at him threw;
He did them aske, who all that passed gan repeat.
Thence forth I passed to the second gate,
And know the moniments of passed times:
For houres but dayes; for weekes, that passed were,
Yet as he passed by, the Pagan threw
Thence forth they passed with that gentle Mayd,
He had not passed farre vpon the strand,
And then to his first quest he passed forth along.
Which when I saw, as they me passed by,
So passed we, till this young man vs met,
And Calidore forth passed to his former payne.
He passed forth with her in faire array,
So forth he passed thorough that daies paine,
And passed forth, to follow his first enterprise.
By this the other, which was passed by,
As if he would haue passed through him quight:
And baffuld so, that all which passed by,
But since things passed none may now restore,
And speaking markes of passed monuments,
And snar at all, that euer passed by:
In peace may passen ouer Lethe lake,
And suffered them to passen quietly:
In the wide sea, they needes must passen by,
That none durst passen through that perilous glade.
And through the ford to passen did assay;
In forreine landes, and all which passen by,
New merth, her passenger to entertaine:
Where we must land some of our passengers,
All passengers, that none from it can shift:
That mote the passengers thereto allure;
Whose manner was all passengers to stay,
All passers by, to tast their lushious wine,
And lightly mounted, passeth on his way,
So passeth, in the passing of a day,
Ne Poets wit, that passeth Painter farre
Prouidence heauenly passeth liuing thought,
Into his waters, as he passeth downe,
Whose fruitfull seede farre passeth those in land,
With paines farre passing that long wandring Greeke,
Shall follow you. So passing forth she him obaid.
Which passing through, on euery side them stood
Of salues and med'cines, which had passing priefe,
Whose passing price vneath was to be told;
Through passing brightnesse, which did quite co[n]found
And him so rudely passing by, did brush
To proofe of passing wonders hath full often vsd.
So passing persant, and so wondrous bright,
But lightly shunned it, and passing by,
And in Amours the passing houres to spend,
By whom they passing, spake vnto them nought.
Far passing th'hight of men terrestriall;
Who passing by, forth led her guestes anone
passing through perils great,
They passing by, that griesly mouth did see,
They passing by, a goodly Ship did see,
And trembled, as them passing they beheld:
Thence passing forth, they shortly do arriue,
So did he eke Sir Guyon passing by:
Whom passing by she happened to meet:
So passeth, in the passing of a day,
And scarse them leasure gaue, her passing to behold.
These straunger knights through passing, forth were led
And passing Dee with hardy enterprise,
And passing speede, that shortly he her ouerhent.
These twinnes, men say, (a thing far passing thought)
And all the wyles of wemens wits knew passing well.
Of passing valew, and of great renowme,
The whiles the passing brightnes her fraile sences dazed.
And passing by, his name discouered,
But Scudamour for passing great despight
And passing forth with furious affret,
And therein sate a Ladie passing faire
For passing ioy, which so great maruaile brings,
And passing beautie did eftsoones reueale,
Farre passing Bronteus, or Pynacmon great,
Which passing through the eares, would pierce the hart,
They passing forth kept on their readie way,
Passing the measure of my feeble powre,
Farre passing that, which by surpassing skill
Thus passing th'euening well, till time of rest,
She wondred at the workemans passing skill,
And passing litle further, commen were,
His name was Awe; by whom they passing in
By whom they passing, through the thickest preasse,
They passing by, were guyded by degree
Thence passing forth, into the hall he came,
And passing well expert in single fight,
Together with this Ladie, passing on the plaine.
Till that by fortune, passing all foresight,
Seeing the vgly Monster passing by,
Fayles of her souse, and passing by doth hurt no more.
Thence passing forth, not farre away he found,
For passing ioy, which did all into pitty melt.
In this great passion of vnwonted lust,
He in great passion all this while did dwell,
At last whenas the dreadfull passion
Therewith she gan her passion to renew,
Such restlesse passion did all night torment
And chaunge of hew great passion did bewray;
And much asswag'd the passion of his plight,
When raging passion with fierce tyrannie
But when strong passion, or weake fleshlinesse
Whilst reason blent through passion, nought descride,
And calme the tempest of his passion wood;
Tempring the passion with aduizement slow,
Yet with strong reason maistred passion fraile,
And the strong passion mard her modest grace,
And ransackt all her veines with passion entire.
At last the passion past she thus him answered.
But if the passion mayster thy fraile might,
Full of soft passion and vnwonted smart:
With reason dew the passion to subdew,
So strong is passion, that no reason heares.
That each the other gan with passion great,
And euer when his passion is allayd,
Whereby the passion grew more fierce and faine,
Which losse her made like passion also proue.
Through iealous passion weeping inly wroth,
Vnto the passion, that her heart opprest,
The troublous passion of my pensiue mind,
With franticke passion, and with furie fraught;
Would haue the passion hid, and vp arose withall.
But still his passion grew more violent and strong.
To rule the stubborne rage of passion blinde:
Till the sharpe passion being ouerpast,
For other none such passion can contriue
That godly King and Queene did passionate,
So straungely passioned, and to her gently sayd,
Some argument of matter passioned;
Distempred through misrule and passions bace:
By knowen signes and passions, which I see,
Both coosen passions of distroubled spright,
And all the passions, that in man may light,
Of all the passions in the mind thou vilest art.
T'expresse his passions, which his reason did empeach.
And al the passio[n]s heale, which wou[n]d the weaker spright.
Of needments at his backe. Thus as they past,
Of past: true is, that true loue hath no powre
So forth they past, and all the way they spent
At last when perils all I weened past,
For sorrowes past; their griefe is with them gone:
Dead is Sans-foy, his vitall paines are past,
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
At perill past, and yet in doubt ne dares
That they the woods are past, & come now to the plaine.
Vnkindnesse past, they gan of solace treat,
When all was past, tooke vp his forlorne weed,
What hath poore Virgin for such perill past,
Is not great grace to helpe him ouer past,
Had past the paines of hell, and long enduring night.
Henceforth take heede of that thou now hast past,
They were farre past the passage, which he spake,
The third things past could keepe in memoree,
Then thought the Prince all perill sure was past,
The Palmer seeing them in safetie past,
That they it past, and shortly gan descry
Yet nought they feard, but past on hardily,
At last the passion past she thus him answered.
At last the fury past, to former hew
With some late perill, which he hardly past,
But past awhile, when she fit season saw
In thousand shiuers, and so forth beside her past.
Past through his eyes, and secretly did glyde
And many perils past in forreine lands,
Which they had past with mickle ieopardy,
And call aloud for helpe, ere helpe were past;
As on aduenture by the way he past:
And march not past the mountenaunce of a shot.
Whom whenas Scudamour saw past the fire,
The vtmost rowme, and past the formest dore,
Then when the second watch was almost past,
But being past, he thus began amaine;
And pleasaunt bord, they past forth on their way,
Diuide their works, haue past through heuen sheene,
Thence forth she past into his dreadfull den,
